content: Being Canadian I'm constantly having to switch between metric and imperial. Recently I was wondering if Americans who haven't had any science studies know about the decimal system. I guess it's used in high school math isn't it? I'm forgetting those years
@Herb I did horrible at math in (American) school. I still don't fully understand how the decimal system works :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:

I mention Canada because decades ago our government switched some things over to metric but not others. And there are still plenty of people using imperial (pounds, inches, feet, miles, F). The temperature annoys me because I can't easily translate

I've been rebuilding my shed and having to force myself to use centimeters because it's just easier than trying to figure out and remember the fraction of an inch. "Was it 7/8 or 13/16?" I can just say 0.8 etc
Our tape measures have both so we confuse ourselves more
Than I thought why don't I just use decimals with inches? Maybe the tape measures should show that
But that's a slippery slope to making imperial easier to use and we don't want that

@Herb - In my school days, 40 years ago, we all learned about the decimal system. But, at the time there was movement towards adopting it, which I think has gone away. I am not sure how much attention it gets in schools today. But, it has crept into daily life in a partial way.

We see it around us all the time on packaging and on our rulers. But, I think it's also pretty easy to ignore it if you want.
What do you mean by 'decimal system'? Do you mean most Americans don't know things like 0.5, 6.72, etc.? Surely you use that with money, right?

What do you mean by 'decimal system'?

I read this mean the metric system. But, I might have misunderstood. You are correct, decimals themselves are very common for other purposes, including money. But, we don't really use decimals very much in imperial measurements. We say 4 1/2 feet or 1 3/4 miles, most of the time. I suppose in the case of miles, we sometimes use decimals.

I find the decimal system much easier to deal with. Also, 0° as the freezing point and 100° as boiling point makes more sense, and is easier to teach to kids, and to commit to memory in general than 32° and 212° respectively :shrug:
0 °F, was established as the freezing temperature of a solution of brine made from a mixture of water, ice, and ammonium chloride
...sure, as if anybody can get that solution as easy as water :sweat_smile:

The other limit established was his best estimate of the average human body temperature (set at 96 °F; about 2.6 °F less than the modern value due to a later redefinition of the scale).[3] However, he noted a middle point of 32 °F, to be set to the temperature of ice water.
:face_palm:
...that's a recipe to get kids to hate science ^^
